newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai government budget misleading - opposition.
newsitem.headline: Thai government budget misleading - opposition.

text.p: Thai opposition leaders on Thursday accused the government of misleading the public with its 1998 budget, and warned that current spending plans could give the country a deficit in 1997/98.

Former finance minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda of the opposition Democrat Party led the attack on the proposed 982-billion-baht ($39.3-billion) budget on the second day of a scheduled three-day debate on the budget bill in parliament.

Tarrin said the government, which has seen its tax revenue crumble this year due to a severe economic downturn, would end the 1997/98 (October-September) fiscal year with a 45-billion-baht budget deficit.
When the government introduced the bill in parliament on Wednesday it projected a balanced, deficit-free budget for 1997/98, following a 63.16-billion-baht deficit in 1996/97.
Tarrin predicted that Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh's six-party coalition would post a slightly higher 65-billion-baht deficit in the current fiscal year.

"The government will fail in its goal of pursuing a balanced budget if it adopts the 982-billion-baht expenditure bill...it is risking the credibility of Thailand's last defence wall, its fiscal discipline if it refuses to trim the budget for next year," Tarrin said during the debate.

Cabinet ministers said this week the government would ask state enterprises to raise their revenue contributions next year by 16 billion baht to help fill a possible revenue shortfall. They said no tax hikes were being planned.
Chavalit has called the budget an austerity bill that reflected the Thai economic slowdown that began before his government took office last November.
Thailand faces its slowest economic growth in more than a decade this year. The prime minister has forecast growth would ease to 5.6 percent this year against 6.4 percent posted in 1996.
Adding to Thailand's troubles are sluggish exports, high interest rates, a baht that has come under speculative attack and a stock market at eight-year lows.
Thailand's ailing and cash-strapped finance sector is also in disarray, with heavy loan over-exposure to the glutted and depressed property sector.
The government last month trimmed the 1997/98 budget by 26.59 billion baht, taking into account an expected tax revenue shortfall in that fiscal year.
Tarrin said a government plan to squeeze more revenue out of state enterprises would hurt business and the general public as these agencies would be forced to raise utility charges.

Education Minister Sukavit Rangsitphol bore the brunt of opposition attacks for the second day for his proposed 9.7 billion baht in planned subsidies for government and private educational institutions.
The opposition accused Sukavit of over-spending on what it called his loosely worded plan to buy computers for small rural schools.
